Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is running around in a supermarket, and the mother needs to correct the behavior
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: I glanced at my watch, heart pounding. My volunteer shift started in fifteen minutes, and I was the only one with the keys to open the community center. I pictured the line of people already waiting outside, counting on me to let them in. But right now, I was in the supermarket with my son, who was darting between aisles, giggling as he dodged my attempts to catch him. Other shoppers shot me disapproving looks. I knew I should stop him, kneel down, and explain why running indoors was wrong—teach him about respect and discipline, just like I always promised myself I would. But every minute spent here meant another minute those people would be left standing in the cold, maybe thinking I’d forgotten them. My son’s laughter echoed, and I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. I wanted to be the mother who taught her child right from wrong, but I also didn’t want to let down the people who needed me at the center. My hands trembled as I reached for my son, torn between two promises I couldn’t keep at once.
